name: NPR
text: Studies of inexpensive steroids, including the generic drug dexamethasone, have found that they can reduce deaths in patients hospitalized with serious cases of COVID-19. https://t.co/nuyF3fcqwU

name: NPR
text: The number of COVID-19 cases has increased by some 220% in Lebanon after the massive explosion at Beirut’s port, which forced 3 of the capital city’s major hospitals to close and partially damaged 3 others. https://t.co/vScMXeq44f

name: NPR
text:
Among the universe of young Republicans, research suggests that President Trump's appeal may have its limits.

"If we don't fix this right now within the party, we're going to have a problem going forward," says a 20-year-old student.
https://t.co/sj4EDwHHL0

name: NPR
text:
"In this instance of the Trump presidency, Trump's use of power is so unusual that we have a phenomenon here where the people around the president are trying to stop him," says New York Times reporter Michael Schmidt. (@nprfreshair)
https://t.co/aghElTavdy

name: NPR
text:
It's been about 5 months since the U.S. economy ground to a halt. We want to hear how the pandemic has affected your job situation, your finances and your family.

Please fill out the form linked here — and an NPR reporter may contact you for a story ⤵
https://t.co/Fl55CIyE6v

name: NPR
text: Carmen Best, Seattle's first Black woman police chief, says she was excluded from conversations around reimagining the future of policing, which made it "very difficult to move forward and make the changes needed." https://t.co/ZevzkjRu6g

name: NPR
text:
The tally of coronavirus infections tracing back to the Sturgis Motorcycle Rally has surpassed 260 — with the first known death of an attendee reported in Minnesota.

Nearly half a million bikers flocked to South Dakota for the event.
https://t.co/CZsPJ4GUAA

name: NPR
text: The Decemberists' Colin Meloy talks about "Slint, Spiderland," a meditation on the banality of everyday life in the midst of an international emergency. https://t.co/4MN9CXghwB

name: NPR
text:
It would have been unimaginable only weeks ago to see Israeli officials fly to the United Arab Emirates and walk out onto a red carpet. 

And that wasn't the only unusual part of this visit.
https://t.co/S0t2IHT1yH

name: NPR
text:
Fantastic Negrito’s "How Long?" is a challenge to everyone, simultaneously exhorting Black people to recognize that "we gotta fight" — and slinging an uncompromising demand for progress at the entire world.
https://t.co/zrFQYg65Jb

name: NPR
text:
A combination of two experimental drugs appears to slow the decline of patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, an illness often known as ALS or Lou Gehrig's disease.
https://t.co/lE2AqO4Ogv

name: NPR
text:
Officials in Kenosha have lifted the nightly curfew. A lawsuit was filed by protesters Tuesday, alleging officials enforced the curfew selectively by targeting those protesting police brutality.
https://t.co/IV62LWxgRZ
